"Come Thou Fount of Every Blessing"  
---  
[Hymn](/wiki/Hymn "Hymn")  
Written | 1757 (1757)  
Text | by [Robert Robinson](/wiki/Robert_Robinson_\(hymnist\) "Robert Robinson \(hymnist\)")  
Meter | 8.7.8.7  
Melody | by John Wyeth "Nettleton"  
  
"**Come Thou Fount of Every Blessing** " is a [Christian](/wiki/Christian
"Christian") [hymn](/wiki/Hymn "Hymn") written by the 18th century
[pastor](/wiki/Pastor "Pastor") and [hymnist](/wiki/Hymnist "Hymnist") [Robert
Robinson](/wiki/Robert_Robinson_\(hymnist\) "Robert Robinson \(hymnist\)").
Robert Robinson penned the words at age 22 in the year 1757.[1]

##
Tunes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Come_Thou_Fount_of_Every_Blessing&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Tunes")]

In the United States, the hymn is usually set to an American folk tune known
as "Nettleton", composed by printer John Wyeth,[2] or possibly by [Asahel
Nettleton](/wiki/Asahel_Nettleton "Asahel Nettleton").[3] In the United
Kingdom, the hymn is also often set to the tune "Normandy" by C Bost.[4] The
"Nettleton" tune is used extensively in partial or full quotation by the
American composer [Charles Ives](/wiki/Charles_Ives "Charles Ives"), in such
works as the [First String Quartet](/wiki/String_Quartet_No._1_\(Ives\)
"String Quartet No. 1 \(Ives\)") and the piano quintet and song "The Innate".
The "Nettleton" tune is also quoted at the end of "My Trundle Bed" by Tullius
C. O'Kane. A [shape note](/wiki/Shape_note "Shape note") song called
"Warrenton" also has been sung with a chorus being in 4/4 time or 2/2 cut
time; to fit the text to this melody, the second half of each verse is omitted
and replaced with a refrain of "I am bound for the kingdom, will you come to
glory with me? / Hallelujah, praise the Lord!"[5]

## Cover
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Come_Thou_Fount_of_Every_Blessing&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cover versions")]

  * It has been covered by the [David Crowder Band](/wiki/David_Crowder_Band "David Crowder Band") on their 1999 album _[All I Can Say](/wiki/All_I_Can_Say "All I Can Say")_.
  * Christian rock band [Jars of Clay](/wiki/Jars_of_Clay "Jars of Clay") has also covered the song, as well as veteran Christian artist [Scott Wesley Brown](/wiki/Scott_Wesley_Brown "Scott Wesley Brown").
  * [Sufjan Stevens](/wiki/Sufjan_Stevens "Sufjan Stevens") recorded a version for his _Hark! Songs for Christmas_ album, which reached 122 in the US charts and is featured in the closing minutes of the season four premiere episode of _[Friday Night Lights](/wiki/Friday_Night_Lights_\(TV_series\) "Friday Night Lights \(TV series\)")_.
  * [Gateway Worship](/wiki/Gateway_Worship "Gateway Worship") performed the song on their album _Living for You_ and added a chorus to the song, calling it "Come Thou Fount, Come Thou King".
  * It also appears on [Phil Wickham](/wiki/Phil_Wickham "Phil Wickham")'s album 'sing-a-long'.
  * This song is also sung by Clark Davis in the film _[Love Comes Softly](/wiki/Love_Comes_Softly "Love Comes Softly")_ and is a recurring background music in the film.
  * [Mumford & Sons](/wiki/Mumford_%26_Sons "Mumford & Sons") have covered it in a small amount of their live shows.
  * Leigh Nash has covered it in Hymns and Sacred Songs.
  * Additionally, the [Mormon Tabernacle Choir](/wiki/Mormon_Tabernacle_Choir "Mormon Tabernacle Choir") recorded this hymn as part of their album titled _The Sound of Glory_ , and frequently sing it in their live performances.
  * Christian [punk pop](/wiki/Punk_pop "Punk pop") band [Eleventyseven](/wiki/Eleventyseven "Eleventyseven") covered the hymn in their _[Good Spells EP](/wiki/Good_Spells_\(EP\) "Good Spells \(EP\)")_.
  * Gospel recording artist [Anthony Brown and group therAPy](/wiki/Anthony_Brown_\(Gospel_musician\) "Anthony Brown \(Gospel musician\)") covered the first verse of the hymn in the song "Without You" on their sophomore album _Everyday Jesus_.
  * Pop musician [Adam Young](/wiki/Owl_City "Owl City") posted his version on his [Soundcloud](/wiki/Soundcloud "Soundcloud") page

The lyrics, which dwell on the theme of [divine grace](/wiki/Divine_grace
"Divine grace"), are based on 1 Samuel 7:12, in which the
[prophet](/wiki/Prophet "Prophet") [Samuel](/wiki/Samuel "Samuel") raises a
stone as a monument, saying, "Hitherto hath the Lord helped us"
([KJV](/wiki/King_James_Version "King James Version")). The English
transliteration of the name Samuel gives to the stone is
_[Ebenezer](/wiki/Eben-Ezer "Eben-Ezer")_ , meaning Stone of Help. The unusual
word _Ebenezer_ commonly appears in hymnal presentations of the lyrics (verse
2).
